lesson.name: Lesson 2.9 Writing and Solving Inequalities in One Variable

page.title: 2.9.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will write and solve inequalities to answer questions about a situation. You will also practice finding the solution set to an inequality by reasoning about its composition and parts.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Analyze the structure of an inequality in one variable to help determine if the solution is greater or less than the solution to the related equation.
  • Write and solve inequalities to answer questions about a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.9.1: Writing an Inequality to Represent a Constraint
  • 2.9.2: Using Inequalities to Solve a Problem
    • 2.9.2: Self Check 
    • 2.9.2: Additional Resources
  • 2.9.3: Different Ways of Solving an Inequality
    • 2.9.3: Self Check 
    • 2.9.3: Additional Resources
  • 2.9.4: Matching Inequalities and Solutions (Optional)
  • 2.9.5: Solving Inequalities
    • 2.9.5: Self Check 
    • 2.9.5: Additional Resources
  • 2.9.6: Writing Inequalities to Represent a Situation 

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 2.9.7: Practice
  • 2.9.8: Lesson Summary

page.title: 2.9.1: Writing an Inequality to Represent a Constraint
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Kiran is getting dinner for his drama club on the evening of their final rehearsal. He plans to buy some prepared dishes from a supermarket.

  • The budget for the dinner is $60.
  • The prepared dishes are sold by the pound, at $5.29 per pound. 
  • He also plans to buy two large bottles of sparkling water at $2.49 each.

  1. Represent the constraints in the situation mathematically. If you use variables, specify what each one means.

Enter your answer here:

\(5.29p+2(2.49)\leq60\), or \(5.29p+4.98\leq60\). \(p\) is the pounds of prepared foods Kiran could buy without going over budget.


  1. How many pounds of prepared dishes can Kiran buy? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Up to 10.4 pounds, or \(p\leq10.4\). Sample reasoning: After removing the cost of sparkling water, Kiran still has $55.02. Dividing that amount by 5.29 gives 10.4.

page.title: 2.9.2: Using Inequalities to Solve a Problem
page.contents:
Activity

Han is about to mow some lawns in his neighborhood. His lawn mower has a 5-gallon fuel tank, but Han is not sure how much gasoline is in the tank.

He knows, however, that the lawn mower uses 0.4 gallon of gasoline per hour of mowing.


  1. What are all the possible values for \(x\), the number of hours Han can mow without refilling the lawn mower?
  2. Write one or more inequalities to represent your response. Be prepared to explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

  1. \(x\;\leq\;12.5,\;\) and \(x\;\geq\;0\).
  2. \(x\;\leq\;\frac5{0.4}\) or \(x\;\geq\;12.5\) and \(x\;\geq\;0\). If the tank is completely full, Han can mow for at most 12.5 hours without refilling. If it is completely empty, he can mow for 0 hours. It is not possible for Han to mow for a negative number of hours.


Video: Using Inequalities to Solve a Problem

Watch the following video to learn more about how to solve a problem using inequalities.

page.title: 2.9.2: Self Check
page.contents: Samantha is feeding the horses at her barn. She has 6 buckets of oats. If each horse eats \(\frac34\) bucket of oats, how many horses can she feed at most?

answer.answer_text: \(x\leq6\), Samantha can feed a maximum of 6 horses.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Each horse does not eat 1 bucket of oats. Did you start with the inequality \(\frac34x\leq6\)? The answer is Samantha can feed up to 8 horses.

answer.answer_text: \(x\leq4\), Samantha can feed a maximum of 4 horses.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Is 5 a solution? Did you start with the inequality \(\frac34x\leq6\)? The answer is Samantha can feed up to 8 horses.

answer.answer_text: \(x\leq8\), Samantha can feed a maximum of 8 horses.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: \(x\leq8\) means Samantha can feed up to 8 horses.

answer.answer_text: \(x\leq10\), Samantha can feed a maximum of 10 horses.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Is 9 a solution? Did you start with the inequality \(\frac34x\leq6\)? The answer is Samantha can feed up to 8 horses.

page.title: 2.9.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Using Inequalities to Solve a Problem

Let’s look at an example where we might be able to solve a problem using inequalities.

A school is repainting its classroom walls. The school has at most 30 gallons of paint. The painter needs \(\frac52\) gallons of paint for each classroom. How many classrooms can the school paint at most?

We know that the answer is greater than or equal to 0 classrooms, so \(x\geq0\).

We also know that each classroom requires \(\frac52\) or 2.5 gallons of paint.

Let’s take a guess at how many classrooms and check if we are close to the solution. How many gallons of paint would we need to paint 10 classrooms?

\(10 × 2.5 = 25\), and since \(25 < 30\), it could be possible for the school to paint 10 classrooms.

We can try 11 classrooms. 

\(11 × 2.5 = 27.5\), and since \(27.5 < 30\), it could be possible for the school to paint 11 classrooms.

We can try 12 classrooms. 

\(12 × 2.5 = 30\), and since \(30 = 30\), the most classrooms the school could paint is 12 classrooms.

Try It: Using Inequalities to Solve a Problem

While working in a car factory, a worker can use a drill for as long as the batteries last. The worker has at most 9 fully charged batteries. Each car the worker helps assemble uses \(\frac34\) of a full battery. 

  1. What are all of the possible values for \(c\), the number of cars the worker can help assemble?

  2. Write one or more inequalities to represent your response. Be prepared to explain or show your reasoning.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work

Here is how to solve:

  1. \(c\leq12\) and \(c\geq0\). 

  2. If the worker has 9 fully charged batteries, they can help assemble 12 cars. If the worker has no batteries, they can assemble 0 cars. It is not possible for the worker to assemble less than 0 cars.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.9.4: Matching Inequalities and Solutions (Optional)
page.contents:
Optional Activity

Match each inequality to a graph that represents its solutions. Be prepared to explain or show your reasoning.

  1. \(6x\;\leq\;3x\)
  2. \(\frac14x>-\frac12\)
  3. \(5x+4\geq7x\)
  4. \(8x-2<-4(x-1)\)
  5. \(\frac{4x-1}3>-1\)
  6. \(\frac{12}5-\frac x5\leq x\)

Enter your answer here:

  1. Graph F (for \(x\leq0\))
  2. Graph E (for \(x>-2\))
  3. Graph B (for \(x\leq2\))
  4. Graph D (for \(x<12\))
  5. Graph A (for \(x>-12\))
  6. Graph C (for \(x\geq2\))

page.title: 2.9.5: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solving Linear Inequalities

A linear inequality is much like a linear equation—but the equal sign is replaced with an inequality sign. So, when we solve linear equations, we are able to use the properties of equality to add, subtract, multiply, or divide both sides and still keep the equality. Similar properties hold true for inequalities.

We can add or subtract the same quantity from both sides of an inequality and still keep the inequality. For example:


        


Notice that the inequality sign stayed the same.

This leads us to the Addition and Subtraction Properties of Inequality.

Addition and Subtraction Properties of Inequality

For any numbers \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\), if \(a<b\), then

\(a+c<b+c\)       \(a−c<b−c\)

For any numbers \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\), if \(a>b\), then

\(a+c>b+c\)       \(a−c>b−c\)

We can add or subtract the same quantity from both sides of an inequality and still keep the inequality.

What happens to an inequality when we divide or multiply both sides by a constant?

Let’s first multiply and divide both sides by a positive number.


The inequality signs stayed the same.

Does the inequality stay the same when we divide or multiply by a negative number?


Notice that when we filled in the inequality signs, the inequality signs reversed their direction.

When we divide or multiply an inequality by a positive number, the inequality sign stays the same. When we divide or multiply an inequality by a negative number, the inequality sign reverses.

This gives us the Multiplication and Division Properties of Inequality.

Multiplication and Division Properties of Inequality

For any numbers \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\),

multiply or divide by a positive

if \(a< b\) and \(c > 0\), then \(ac < bc\) and \(\frac ac<\frac bc\)

if \(a> b\) and \(c > 0\), then \(ac > bc\) and \(\frac ac>\frac bc\)

Multiply or divide by a negative

if \(a< b\) and \(c < 0\), then \(ac > bc\) and \(\frac ac>\frac bc\)

if \(a> b\) and \(c < 0\), then \(ac < bc\) and \(\frac ac<\frac bc\)

When we divide or multiply an inequality by a:

  • positive number, the inequality stays the same.
  • negative number, the inequality reverses.

Sometimes when solving an inequality, as in the next example, the variable ends up on the right. We can rewrite the inequality in reverse to get the variable to the left.

\(x>a\) has the same meaning as \(a<x\).

Think about it as “If Xander is taller than Andy, then Andy is shorter than Xander.”


EXAMPLE

Solve each inequality. Graph the solution on the number line, and write the solution in interval notation.

  1. \(x\;–\;38\;\leq\;34\)

  2. \(–15 < 38z\)


Solution

1.

Add \(\frac38\) to both sides of the inequality.

Simplify.

Graph the solution on the number line.      

Write the solution in interval notation.


2.

Multiply both sides of the inequality by \(\frac53\).
Since \(\frac53\) is positive, the inequality stays the same.

Simplify.

Rewrite with the variable on the left.

Graph the solution on the number line.

Write the solution in interval notation.


Try It: Solving Linear Inequalities

Solve the following linear inequalities:

  1. \(9y<​​54\)

  1. \(-13m\;\geq\;65\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

1.

Divide both sides of the inequality by 9; since  
9 is positive, the inequality stays the same.

Simplify.

Graph the solution on the number line.

Write the solution in interval notation.


2.

Divide both sides of the inequality by \(-13\).
Since \(-13\) is negative, the inequality reverses.

Simplify.

Graph the solution on the number line.

Write the solution in interval notation.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.9.6: Writing Inequalities to Represent a Situation
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Lin’s job pays $8.25 an hour plus $10 of transportation allowance each week. She has to work at least 5 hours a week to keep the job, and she can earn up to $175 per week, including $10 to cover transportation per week.

  1. Represent this situation mathematically. If you use variables, specify what each one means.
  2. How many hours per week can Lin work? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers.

  1. \(8.25h\;+\;10\;\leq\;175\) and \(h\;\geq\;5\), where \(h\) represents the number of hours Lin works in a week.
  2. At least 5 hours and at most 20 hours (or \(5\leq\;h\;\leq20\)). Sample reasoning: The maximum amount she could earn, not including the transportation allowance, is $165. That amount is equal to 20 hours of work, \(\frac{165}{8.25}=20)\).

page.title: 2.9.3: Different Ways of Solving an Inequality
page.contents:
Activity

Andre and Priya used different strategies to solve the following inequality, but they reached the same solution.

\(2(2x + 1.5) < 18 − x\)

  1. Make sense of each strategy until you can explain what each student has done.

Andre

\(\begin{array}{rcl}2(2x\;+\;1.5)\;&=&\;18\;-\;x\\4x+3&=&18-x\\4x\;-\;15\;&=&\;-x\\-15\;&=&\;-5x\\3\;&=&\;x\end{array}\)

Testing to see if \(x = 4\) is a solution:

\(\begin{array}{rcl}2(2⋅4+1.5)\;&<&\;18-4\\2(9.5)\;&<&\;14\\19\;&<&\;14\end{array}\)

The inequality is false, so 4 is not a solution. If a number greater than 3 is not a solution, the solution must be less than 3, or \(x < 3\).

Priya

\(\begin{array}{rcl}2(2x+1.5)&=&18-x\\4x+3&=&18-x\\5x+3&=&18\\5x&=&15\\x&=&3\end{array}\)

In \(4x + 3 = 18 − x\), there is \(4x\) on the left and \(-x\) on the right.

If \(x\) is a negative number, \(4x + 3\) could be positive or negative, but \(18 - x\) will always be positive.

For \(4x + 3 < 18 − x\) to be true, \(x\) must include negative numbers or \(x\) must be less than 3.

  1. Here are four inequalities.

    1. \(15p>-10\)

    2. \(4(x+7)\leq4(2x+8)\)

    3. \(-9n<36\)

    4. \(3c<-2(c-7)\)

Work with a partner to decide on at least two inequalities to solve. Solve one inequality using Andre’s strategy (by testing values on either side of the given solution), while your partner uses Priya’s strategy (by reasoning about the parts of the inequality). Switch strategies for the other inequality.

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some sample responses to compare your answers.

  • No response required.

  • Answers:

  1. \(p>-50\). Sample reasoning (after solving \(15p=-10\) to get \(p=-50\)):

    1. Using Andre’s strategy: Test a value more than or less than \(-50\), and check to see if that value gives a true statement when substituting back to the original inequality.

    2. Using Priya’s strategy: If \(p\) is a negative number that is far away from 0, say \(-100\), then \(15p\) will be less than, not greater than, \(-10\). This means the solutions must include positive numbers, so the solutions must be greater than \(-50\).

  2. \(x\geq-1\). Sample reasoning using Priya’s strategy (after solving \(4(x+7)=4(2x+8)\) and getting \(x=-1\)):

    1. After dividing each side by 4, the left side of the inequality has \(x\), while the right side has \(2x\). This means the expression on the left side will be less than that on the right when \(x\) includes positive numbers, so \(x\) must be greater than or equal to \(-1\). (In other words, for most negative values of \(x\), \(2x\) will be less than \(x\), which would make the inequality untrue.)

  3. \(n>-4\). Sample reasoning using Priya’s strategy (after solving \(-9n=36\) to get \(n=-4\)):

    1. If \(n\) includes large positive numbers, then \(-9n\) will be smaller than 36, so \(n\) must include positive numbers that are greater than \(-4\).

    2. If \(n\) is less than \(-4\), then it would include negative numbers like \(-10\), which means the value of \(-9n\) would be a positive number that is greater than 36, which makes the inequality untrue. So the solution must be greater than \(-4\).

  4. \(c<6\). Sample reasoning using Priya’s strategy (after solving \(3c=-2(c−7)\) and getting \(c=6\)):

    1. The right side of the inequality has \(-2c\), while the left side has \(13c\). If \(c\) is a large positive number, \(-2c\) will be less than \(13c\). If \(c\) is a negative number, \(-2c\) will be positive and greater than \(13c\), so the solution must include negative numbers that are less than 6.




Extending Your Thinking

Using positive integers between 1 and 9 and each positive integer at most once, fill in values to get two constraints so that \(x=7\) is the only integer that will satisfy both constraints at the same time. 

▢x + ▢ < ▢x + ▢

▢x + ▢ >▢ x + ▢

Enter your answer here:

Sample answer:

\(4x + 1 < 3x + 9\)

\(6x + 2 > 5x + 8\)

page.title: 2.9.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Solve the following inequality by solving the related equation and reasoning what the answer may be given the situation.

\(\frac13p<4\)

answer.answer_text: \(p > 12\); The solution to the related equation is \(p = 12\). For \(\frac13p\) to be less than 4, the solution must contain large positive numbers.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: In the inequality, one-third of \(p\) is less than, not greater than, 12. The answer is \(p < 12\).

answer.answer_text: \(p < 12\); The solution to the related equation is \(p = 12\). Since \(\frac13p\) must be less than 4, the solution cannot include large positive numbers, so numbers larger than 12 cannot be included in the solution.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Any negative number substituted into \(\frac13p\) will be less than 4, so the solution must include negative numbers.

answer.answer_text: \(p < \frac34\); The related equation is \(p = frac34\). Since the solution set must contain negative numbers, \(p\) must be less than \(\frac34\).
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Multiplying both sides of the related equation by 3 results in \(p = 12\). The answer is \(p < 12\).

answer.answer_text: \(p < \frac43\); The related equation is \(p = \frac43\). Since the solution set must contain negative numbers, \(p\) must be less than \(\frac43\).
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: For the related equation, instead of multiplying one-third by 4, multiply both sides of the equation by 3. The answer is \(p < 12\).

page.title: 2.9.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Reasoning about Solution Sets to Linear Inequalities

You can derive a lot of information about the solution set to an inequality by studying the inequality itself.

Let’s look at the inequality shown.

\(12x>-3(x−1)\)

The left side of the inequality contains \(12x\). The right side of the inequality contains \(-3x\).

We can think to ourselves: “What values of \(x\) would make \(12x\) greater than \(-3x\)?”

If \(x\) is a large positive number, then \(12x\) will still be positive. If \(x\) is a large positive number, then \(-3x\) will be a negative number. This makes the inequality true, so the solution set must include large positive numbers.


Let’s solve the related equation.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}12x&>&-3(x-1)\\12x\;&=&\;–3(x\;–\;1)\\12x\;&=&\;–3x\;+3\\72x\;&=&\;3\\x\;&=&\;67\end{array}\)

Since we know that the solution set must include large positive numbers, then \(x > 67\) must be the solution to the inequality.

Try It: Reasoning about Solution Sets to Linear Inequalities

Solve the related equation for each inequality. Use what you know about the inequality to determine the solution set.

  1. \(-5y\geq30\)

  2.  \(14p<-4\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to solve:

  1. The solution to the related equation is \(y = -6\). Since any positive number substituted for \(y\) makes \(-5y\) a negative value, then the solution set cannot include positive numbers. This means the solution is \(y\leq-6\).

  2. The solution to the related equation is \(p = -1\). Since any positive number substituted for \(p\) makes \(14p\) a positive value, the solution set cannot include positive numbers. This means the solution is \(p < -1\).

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self-check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.9.5: Solving Inequalities
page.contents:
Activity

In this activity, we’re going to solve inequalities. Work with a partner to solve each inequality given. Then match it with the number line representing its solution.

As you complete the activity, discuss with your partner how you know each number line is the solution to its inequality. 

When you think you’ve found the correct number line for an inequality, substitute a test point that is on the highlighted part of the number line into the inequality. Is it true?

Try a test point that is not highlighted. Is the inequality false?

  1. \(x\;–\;4\;\leq\;–6\;\)    
  1. \(x\;+\;6\;\geq\;8\;\)  
  1. \(4x\;\leq\;8\)   
  1. \(–12x\;\leq\;1\;\)  

Enter your answer here:

  1. C

  2. A

  3. D

  4. B

For each of the inequalities above, match it to the property you used to solve.


  1. \(x\;–\;4\;\leq\;–6\)    
  1. Multiplication Property of Inequality
  1. \(x\;+\;6\;\leq\;8\)   
  1. Addition Property of Inequality
  1. \(4x\;\leq\;8\)   
  1. Division Property of Inequality
  1. \(–12x\;\leq\;1\) 
  1. Subtraction Property of Inequality

Enter your answer here:

  1. B

  2. D

  3. C or A

  4. A or C


  1. Is there anything unique about the method used to solve \(–12x\leq1\)? Explain.

Enter your answer here:

Yes. The inequality contains a less than or equal to symbol \((\leq)\). However, in the solution there is a greater than or equal to symbol \((\geq)\). When using the Multiplication and Division Properties of Inequality, you must reverse the symbol when you multiply or divide by a negative number.

page.title: 2.9.5: Self Check
page.contents:
Solve the inequality. Which number line represents the solution?

\(–\;\frac13m\;\leq\;5\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This number line represents \(m\leq15\). However, substituting \(-16\) makes the inequality false. The answer is D, or \(m\geq-15\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This number line represents \(m\geq15\). However, substituting 14 makes the inequality true. The answer is D, or \(m\geq-15\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This number line represents \(m\leq-15\). However, substituting \(-16\) makes the inequality false. The answer is D, or \(m\geq-15\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The correct answer is \(m\geq-15\). Substituting \(-14\) makes the inequality true. Substituting \(-16\) makes the inequality false.

page.title: 2.9.7: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson. Enter Only Integers

1. Xander is loading a pallet with boxes that each weighs 45 pounds. The pallet can safely support no more than 900 pounds. How many boxes can he safely load onto the pallet?
____ boxes or less

Correct! 20

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 20. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. The elevator in Yehire’s apartment building has a sign that says the maximum weight is 2,100 pounds. If the average weight of one person is 150 pounds, how many people can safely ride the elevator?
a maximum of ___ people

Correct! 14

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 14. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. Jaden is looking at apartments with three of his friends. They want the monthly rent to be no more than $2,360. If the roommates split the rent evenly among the four of them, what is the maximum rent each will pay?
$____

Correct! 14

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 590. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. Melody got a $20 gift card for the coffee shop. Her favorite iced drink costs $3.79. What is the maximum number of drinks she can buy with the gift card?
____ drinks

Correct! 5

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. Teegan likes to play golf. He has budgeted $60 next month for the driving range. It costs him $10.55 for a bucket of balls each time he goes. What is the maximum number of times he can go to the driving range next month?
____ drinks

Correct! 5

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. Ryan charges his neighbors $17.50 to wash their car. How many cars must he wash next summer if his goal is to earn at least $1,500?
____ cars

Correct! 5

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 86. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. Alejandro’s water bill is $24.80 per month plus $2.20 per ccf (hundred cubic feet) of water. What is the maximum number of ccf Alejandro can use if he wants his bill to be no more than $60?
____ ccf

Correct! 16

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 16. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. Look at the inequality \(5m + 6 < 14 − 2m\). Which of the following is NOT true?

Correct! If m is a negative number, then \(14 − 2m\) will always be negative

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.9.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is if m is a negative number, then \(14 − 2m\) will always be negative.. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

9. Solve the inequality: \(x + 8 > –12\)

Correct! x > -20

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.9.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x > -20\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

10. Solve the inequality: \(x – 15 <–3\)

Correct! \(x < 12\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.9.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x < 12\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

11. Solve the inequality: \(x\;+\;19\;\leq\;23\)

Correct! \(x\;\leq\;4\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.9.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x\;\leq\;4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

12. Solve the inequality: \(7x < –56\)

Correct! \(x < -8\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.9.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x < -8\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

13. Solve the inequality: \(\frac x2\;\;\leq\;\frac52\)

Correct! \(x\;\;\leq\;5\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.9.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x\;\;\leq\;5\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

14. Solve the inequality: \(-3x > 21\)

Correct! \(x < -7\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.9.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x < -7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 2.9.8: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Analyze the structure of an inequality in one variable to help determine if the solution is greater or less than the solution to the related equation.
  • Write and solve inequalities to answer questions about a situation.

    Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

    • 2.9.1: Writing an Inequality to Represent a Constraint
      • In this activity, you practiced writing an inequality to represent a constraint, reasoning about its solutions, and interpreting the solutions.
    • 2.9.2: Using Inequalities to Solve a Problem
      • In this activity, you used inequalities to solve a problem about a situation whose constraints might be unfamiliar and in which multiple quantities are unknown.
    • 2.9.2: Self Check
    • 2.9.3: Different Ways of Solving an Inequality
      • In this activity, you explored some ways to decide whether the solution set to an inequality is greater than or less than a particular boundary value (identified by solving a related equation).
    • 2.9.3: Self Check
    • 2.9.4: Matching Inequalities and Solutions (Optional)
      • In this optional activity, you received additional practice in reasoning about the solutions to inequalities without any context.
    • 2.9.5: Solving Inequalities
      • In this activity, you used the Addition and Subtraction Properties of Inequality to solve different inequalities. You also used the Multiplication and Division Properties of Inequality to solve inequalities. You learned that when using the Multiplication and Division Properties of Inequality, you must reverse the symbol when you multiply or divide by a negative number.
    • 2.9.5: Self Check
    • 2.9.6: Writing Inequalities to Represent a Situation
      • In this activity, you wrote inequalities to represent a situation.

    After these activities, you completed the following practice:

    • 2.9.7: Practice

    Checking In

    On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

    Correct!

    If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
